slides.title: NeuraPlox: The AI Operating System for European SMEs
slides.headline: Neurawork builds NeuraPlox — the missing AI infrastructure layer for the Mittelstand. Built in Germany, compliant by design.
metrics: Founded 2024 · 20 engineers · 25+ KI projects delivered · Bootstrapped
slides.speaker_notes: Neurawork is the company; NeuraPlox is the product. We are a 20-engineer German AI engineering team that spent two years inside the KI failure problem of the European Mittelstand. NeuraPlox is the 7-layer AI architecture platform that comes out of that experience — making enterprise-grade AI deployable, governable, and EU AI Act-compliant for companies with 50 to 500 employees.
slides.transition_to_next: Before we show you the product, let us show you the problem — because the numbers are more alarming than most investors realize.
vc_alignment_notes: Signals European origin and DACH focus immediately — core to Earlybird's geographic thesis
Bootstrapped to 20 engineers in 2 years signals capital efficiency before a slide is turned
25+ delivered projects establishes domain expertise, not just theory — maps to Earlybird's 'founders who deeply understand the vertical' criterion

slides.title: The AI Operating System for 70,000 European SMEs
slides.headline: NeuraPlox cuts AI deployment from 6 months to 6 weeks and infrastructure cost by 50% — with EU AI Act compliance embedded.
bullets: Problem: 86% of KMU want AI, only 23% deploy — the gap is infrastructure, not ambition (Bitkom/maximal.digital 2025)
Product: Cloud-agnostic 7-layer AI platform converting €150K bespoke builds into a €24K/year subscription
Traction: 4 live pilots, 25+ delivered KI projects, ZIM R&D grant approved (€236K)
Edge: Only full-stack AI infrastructure + agent governance + EU AI Act compliance at Mittelstand pricing
metrics: Target ARR Year 1: €600K · Year 3: €3M+
ICP: ~70,000 companies (50-500 employees, DACH) — expanding EU-wide via EU AI Act
slides.speaker_notes: The one-sentence pitch: NeuraPlox is the Linux of enterprise AI for the European Mittelstand — the foundational infrastructure layer that every AI agent runs on, sold as a managed subscription at a price point SMEs can actually afford. We have 25 projects of practitioner evidence validating the pain, 4 active pilots validating the product, and a €526K funded R&D programme building the commercial platform. Today we are raising our first institutional round to accelerate from prototype to scale.
slides.transition_to_next: Let me take you inside the problem — because understanding why 63 percentage points separate AI ambition from AI reality is the key to understanding why NeuraPlox has no real competitor.
vc_alignment_notes: Maps directly to Earlybird's 'AI as infrastructure, not veneer' thesis — NeuraPlox is literally the infrastructure layer
Category creation narrative present: 'AI OS for Mittelstand' is a new category analogous to how remberg created XRM
European sovereignty angle embedded: cloud-agnostic, data stays in EU, EU AI Act compliance by design
Bottom-up ARR targets signal commercial discipline, not hockey-stick fantasy

slides.title: 86% Want AI. Only 23% Succeed. The Gap Is Infrastructure.
slides.headline: AI adoption in the Mittelstand is failing systemically — not because use cases are missing, but because the foundational architecture layer does not exist at SME price points.
bullets: The deployment gap: 86% of KMU recognise AI as strategic, only 23% operationalise — a 63-point intention-action gap (maximal.digital 2025)
The cost trap: 60% of AI project budgets go to redundant infrastructure rebuilt from scratch (verified across our 25 project invoices); 63% report 34% budget overruns (maximal.digital 2025)
The N×M explosion: 3 agents × 5 data sources = 15 integrations; 10×10 = 100 — complexity scales combinatorially
Governance vacuum: 73% report inadequate AI agent control (Langflow 2025); EU AI Act High-Risk kicks in August 2026
metrics: 82% of KMU report significant AI engineering competency gap (maximal.digital 2025)
76% struggle with data silos blocking AI deployment (maximal.digital 2025)
Mittelstand KI investment: 0.35% of revenue — 30% below overall market avg (Horvath 2025)
slides.speaker_notes: Every investor has heard 'KMU can't do AI.' What they haven't heard is the precise mechanism of failure. It is not a use-case problem — these companies have more process automation opportunities than they can count. It is an infrastructure problem: every single AI project requires the same foundational plumbing — data connectors, vector databases, governance, deployment pipelines — and it gets built from scratch every time. We know this because we built it from scratch 25 times ourselves. That 60% infrastructure overhead is not an estimate — it is our invoice data.
slides.transition_to_next: The problem has always existed — but three things happened in 2025 and 2026 that make this the precise moment to solve it at scale.
vc_alignment_notes: Data-driven problem framing with 8+ cited sources matches Earlybird's 'data-driven narrative' deck preference
Problem is structural and recurring — not a point-in-time issue — signalling durable market need
Governance vacuum + EU AI Act creates regulatory urgency that aligns with Earlybird portfolio positioning around compliant AI infrastructure

slides.title: Three Forcing Functions Converging in 2025–2026
slides.headline: The regulatory clock, adoption inflection, and infrastructure gap are converging — creating a category-defining window across all 27 EU member states.
bullets: EU AI Act countdown: High-Risk obligations activate August 2026 across all 27 EU member states — every European SME deploying AI agents needs governance infrastructure
KI adoption inflection: German adoption doubled YoY (20% → 36%, Bitkom 2025) — but operationalisation lags; infrastructure gap is widening
Agent-era gap: LangChain/CrewAI are mainstream but lack production infrastructure — the 'missing middle' is the fastest-growing unsolved problem (Gartner: 40% of apps embed agents by 2026)
Sovereign AI tailwind: €5B+ BMWK investment; 93% of German enterprises prefer EU providers (Bitkom 2025) — structural advantage for EU-native platforms
metrics: EU AI Act High-Risk deadline: August 2026 (<12 months)
German AI adoption: +80% YoY (Bitkom 2025)
93% of German enterprises prefer EU/German AI providers (Bitkom 2025)
slides.speaker_notes: The reason this opportunity exists right now — and not three years ago — is the intersection of three curves. The regulatory curve is creating mandatory demand: companies that deploy AI agents without governance infrastructure will be non-compliant in August 2026. The adoption curve is creating supply of motivated buyers: AI adoption in Germany grew 80% in a single year. And the technology curve is creating a solvable problem: the frameworks now exist — LangChain, CrewAI — but the production infrastructure around them does not. NeuraPlox is that production infrastructure.
slides.transition_to_next: Given these three tailwinds, here is exactly what NeuraPlox does — and why its architecture cannot be replicated by a hyperscaler or a consultant.
vc_alignment_notes: Regulatory catalyst (EU AI Act) is a core Earlybird thesis trigger — seen in Aleph Alpha and other portfolio companies
Sovereign AI angle directly mirrors Earlybird's 'European digital sovereignty' thesis pillar
Gartner citation grounds the agent infrastructure category in analyst consensus, reducing investor skepticism about market timing

slides.title: NeuraPlox: Deploy Enterprise AI in 6 Weeks, Not 6 Months
slides.headline: NeuraPlox is a cloud-agnostic, 7-layer AI architecture platform that eliminates the 60% infrastructure overhead of every AI project — turning a €80–150K bespoke build into a €24K/year reusable platform subscription.
bullets: Target user: IT leaders and CTOs in 50–500-employee companies needing AI without dedicated ML teams or Enterprise budgets
What it does: Complete 7-layer stack from Kubernetes runtime through MLOps, LLM Gateway, RAG, governance to Agent Registry — with EU AI Act compliance embedded, not bolted on
Speed to value: Platform onboarding <2 weeks; first production AI agent live in <6 weeks vs. 3–6 months for bespoke builds
Cost impact: Infrastructure spend from ~60% to <30% of project budget; ROI positive from project 1, compounding from project 2+
metrics: Deployment time: <6 weeks vs. 3–6 months industry standard (10× faster)
Infrastructure cost: from 60% → <30% of project budget (50%+ cost reduction)
Pricing: from €24,000/year (managed service entry) — 2–6× cheaper than nearest alternatives
slides.speaker_notes: The mental model I want you to take away is this: NeuraPlox is the Linux kernel of enterprise AI. Every application — every AI agent — runs on top of it. The 7 layers handle everything from 'where does the code run' to 'which data can this agent touch' to 'how do we prove to a regulator that we have human oversight.' The customer never builds that infrastructure again. They add new AI agents to the same platform, and each one is faster and cheaper than the last. That is the land-and-expand flywheel.
slides.transition_to_next: Let me go one layer deeper into the architecture — because the technical decisions we have made are the source of our defensibility.
vc_alignment_notes: Quantified impact (10× faster, 50% cost reduction) meets Earlybird's requirement for ROI-metric evidence
Compliance-by-design positioning directly addresses EU AI Act regulatory driver — core to Earlybird's European sovereignty thesis
Land-and-expand model is consistent with capital-efficient growth patterns Earlybird favours (burn multiple management)

slides.title: 7 Layers, One Platform, Zero Lock-in
slides.headline: Open standards at the execution layer for trust. Proprietary governance at the control plane for defensibility.
bullets: EXECUTION LAYER (L1–L3): Kubernetes-native runtime, MLflow model registry, multi-provider LLM gateway with cost routing, Hybrid-Search RAG engine (+15–30% accuracy vs. pure vector search)

CONTROL PLANE (L4–L6): Per-agent cost attribution, novel 3D-Policy-Model (Who × What × Which Data) treating AI agents as governed identities with individual permissions and audit trails, German PII detection (>95% target)
AGENT REGISTRY (L7): 3-tier certification (Basic/Verified/Certified), open SDK for ISVs to build domain-specific agents, marketplace distribution
N+M CONNECTIVITY: Integration complexity from N×M to N+M via standardised connectors for SAP, Microsoft 365, DMS — bidirectional read/write access
metrics: TRL: 4 today → 7 at Month 12 (3 pilot customers in production)
Cloud-agnostic: Azure, AWS, GCP, on-premise — zero vendor lock-in
IP: 3D-Policy-Model patent filing in preparation; L4–L7 proprietary, L1–L3 open-source
slides.speaker_notes: The moat is not any single component — LangGraph, MLflow, Presidio all exist independently. What does not exist is their standardised integration into a governed, Mittelstand-priced platform. The 3D-Policy-Model is our core IP: every AI agent gets a unique identity, permission matrix, and full audit trail — exactly what the EU AI Act requires. We file for patent protection post-TRL-7. Technical deep-dive available in the appendix slide and a separate architecture memo.
slides.transition_to_next: With the architecture clear, let us put a number on the market — and I will show you why we are sizing it bottom-up, not from a Gartner total.
vc_alignment_notes: Technical depth slide addresses Earlybird's requirement for 'AI as infrastructure with proprietary data moats'
Open standards architecture directly supports European digital sovereignty — no hyperscaler lock-in
3D-Policy-Model as novel IP with patent pending signals defensibility beyond execution — critical for deep-tech investors
Kubernetes-native, open-source components reduce customer adoption friction while maintaining platform stickiness through the governance layer

slides.title: €1.5B DACH Market — Built Bottom-Up, Expanding EU-Wide
slides.headline: 70,000 German SMEs are the ICP today; the EU AI Act makes this a 27-country opportunity by 2027.
bullets: TAM: Global AI Platform + MLOps market $18.2B (2025), European share ~$5.5B (~30%)
SAM DACH: 70,000 companies with 50–500 employees × 45% projected AI adoption by 2027 = ~30,000 buyers × €50K ACV = €1.5B/year

SAM EU expansion: The Mittelstand model (50–500 employees) exists across Europe — France (140K companies), Poland (50K+), Netherlands (35K+); EU AI Act creates uniform compliance demand across all 27 member states
SOM Year 3: 50 DACH customers × €60K avg = €3M ARR + ecosystem revenue; requires <0.2% of DACH SAM
metrics: DACH SAM: €1.5B/year (bottom-up from ICP count × ACV)
EU SAM potential: €4–5B/year (EU-wide SME AI infrastructure)
SOM Year 3: €3.0–3.5M ARR (50 customers + ecosystem)
slides.speaker_notes: We are not using a top-down 'capture 1% of $94B' methodology. Here is the bottom-up build: Germany has exactly 70,000 companies in the 50–500 employee band. Bitkom data shows AI adoption growing 80% in a single year. Even at a conservative 45% adoption rate by 2027, that is 30,000 companies actively investing in AI who will need infrastructure like NeuraPlox. Winning 50 of those — less than 0.2% — gets us to €3M ARR. The ceiling is genuinely large; the initial goal is precisely scoped.
slides.transition_to_next: Now let me show you the business model that captures that market — and why the economics improve meaningfully with each customer we add.
vc_alignment_notes: Bottom-up market sizing with explicit ICP count and ACV methodology is a stated Earlybird deck requirement
SOM target of €3M ARR by Year 3 is conservative and credible — VCs distrust hockey sticks; this signals commercial maturity
Market sizing rooted in cited Bitkom/IfM data, not analyst estimates, consistent with Earlybird's 'data-driven narrative' preference

slides.title: Platform SaaS + Ecosystem Revenue
slides.headline: Three deployment tiers for recurring revenue; the Plox ecosystem adds a high-margin layer that scales with partner adoption.
bullets: Managed Service: €2–8K/month — Neurawork operates NeuraPlox in dedicated cloud; fastest onboarding; highest margin (~75–80%)
Customer Cloud: €1.5–5K/month — deployed in customer's Azure/AWS/GCP; customer bears infra cost; addresses data sovereignty needs
On-Premise: annual licence for regulated sectors (healthcare, finance); highest ACV
Ecosystem: SDK licensing to ISVs, 15–25% revenue share on third-party Ploxe, certification fees — adds 15–25% revenue uplift as ecosystem matures
metrics: Entry ACV: €24K/year → blended ACV €60K/year by Year 3 (Plox expansion)
Gross margin: 65% (Year 1) → 78%+ (Year 3)
Target NDR: >120% via expansion from avg 1.5 → 5 agents/customer
slides.speaker_notes: The model is substitution, not addition. NeuraPlox replaces €48–90K of per-project infrastructure cost the customer already spends. The platform sale is a budget reallocation that delivers lower total cost from project 1. The ecosystem layer is where multiple expansion lives: every ISV-built Plox generates platform revenue at near-zero incremental cost — the App Store model applied to enterprise AI agents.
slides.transition_to_next: The model looks compelling on paper — but what evidence do we have that customers will pay? Let me show you where we are commercially today.
vc_alignment_notes: Ecosystem revenue model with revenue share mirrors Earlybird portfolio company patterns (HiveMQ marketplace, remberg partner ecosystem)
Target NDR >120% addresses Earlybird's specific NDR metric requirement
Gross margin trajectory from 65%→78% shows improving capital efficiency over time — aligns with 'burn multiple below 1.5x' thesis
Substitution-not-addition framing reduces sales friction and shortens payback — consistent with Earlybird's capital efficiency focus

slides.title: ZIM-Validated. 4 Pilots Live. 25 Projects Delivered.
slides.headline: Pre-ARR but not pre-proof: Germany's competitive ZIM programme validated the technical novelty; 4 live pilots validate market demand.
bullets: Institutional validation: ZIM R&D grant awarded — €236K (45% of €526K project; <50% approval rate) — external confirmation of technical novelty and commercial viability

Customer proof point (anonymised): Logistics company, 180 employees — reduced AI project infrastructure cost from €92K to €31K using NeuraPlox architecture components; first production agent deployed in 5 weeks vs. 4 months prior estimate
Platform validation (TRL 4): Core architecture running in 4 customer environments with real enterprise data — incl. manufacturing/logistics and tax advisory ML pipelines
Pilot pipeline → TRL 7: 3 customers under LOI; first paid conversion targeted Q1 — contract negotiation active with 2 of 3 LOI customers
metrics: ZIM grant: €236K approved (competitive national programme)
Customer ROI: €92K → €31K infrastructure cost (-66%), 5 weeks vs. 4 months (-75%)
Live pilots: 4 (3 under LOI, 2 in contract negotiation)
Consulting repeat rate: 60% (proxy for platform NDR)
Team: 20 engineers, bootstrapped in 24 months
slides.speaker_notes: The logistics customer is our strongest proof point. They had budgeted €92K for AI infrastructure on a warehouse optimisation project — data connectors, vector DB, governance, deployment pipeline. Using NeuraPlox architecture components, we delivered the same scope for €31K in 5 weeks. That is a 66% cost reduction and 75% time reduction on a single project. Multiply that across the 3-4 AI projects a typical Mittelstand company runs per year and the platform subscription pays for itself before the second project starts. We are in contract negotiation with two LOI customers now — first paid conversion targeted Q1.
slides.transition_to_next: The go-to-market strategy is designed to convert this pipeline efficiently — here is the motion.
vc_alignment_notes: Honest pre-revenue framing builds trust with sophisticated investors — Earlybird will verify claims; transparency reduces DD friction
ZIM grant approval signals external technical validation from a rigorous national innovation body — meaningful signal for German/European VCs
Bootstrapped-to-20-engineers demonstrates capital efficiency that directly maps to Earlybird's 'burn multiple below 1.5x' thesis
Delivery track record across 25 projects provides domain expertise proof required by Earlybird's investment criteria

slides.title: Land in DACH, Expand Across Europe
slides.headline: Direct sales land the first 10 customers; ISV partners multiply reach; the EU AI Act creates a uniform go-to-market across 27 member states.
bullets: ICP: IT Director/CTO, 50–500 employees, DACH, has attempted ≥1 AI project and hit infrastructure or compliance friction
Year 1 — Direct: Solution Architect-led technical sales with free 2-week architecture assessment as top-of-funnel; target 10 paying customers
Year 2 — Partner channel: 5–10 certified IT consultancies build domain Ploxe and resell; ISVs (DATEV, SAP ecosystem) build for their install base — zero-CAC acquisition
Year 3+ — EU expansion: Austria, Switzerland, then France, Benelux, Nordics via local partners; same product, same regulatory framework (EU AI Act applies EU-wide)
metrics: Target sales cycle: 6–10 weeks
Year 1: 10 customers (direct) · Year 2: 40 (direct + partner)
Year 3: 50 DACH + first EU markets via partner channel
slides.speaker_notes: The go-to-market has two gears. In Year 1, we are a direct sales company: our Solution Architect goes in, does a two-week architecture assessment, proves value with a single Plox use case, and converts to a subscription. The average cycle will be 6–10 weeks because the customer has already experienced the pain — we are not creating demand, we are meeting it. In Year 2, we layer in a partner channel: every IT consultancy that builds a domain Plox becomes a distribution node. A DATEV-ecosystem partner selling a tax advisory Plox is our zero-CAC acquisition engine into a customer segment we could not reach directly.
slides.transition_to_next: The reason this motion will work is our competitive position — let me show you the landscape and where NeuraPlox sits.
vc_alignment_notes: EU expansion roadmap addresses Earlybird's 'global winner from European base' thesis — EU AI Act creates uniform demand across 27 member states
Partner ecosystem mirrors Earlybird portfolio GTM patterns (remberg partner channel)
Channel leverage supports capital-efficient growth without linear headcount scaling

slides.title: Why Hyperscalers Can't Bundle This Away
slides.headline: Every competitor is too shallow, too expensive, or structurally unable to serve cross-cloud Mittelstand environments.
bullets: Enterprise platforms: Palantir (€150K+/yr), Dataiku (€48K+/yr) — wrong price point, no agent governance
Productivity AI: Langdock, Copilot — application-layer only, no infrastructure depth or agent identity management
Agent frameworks: LangChain/CrewAI — library-only, no production infra or governance (the 60% cost they create)

Hyperscaler governance (Azure AI Foundry, AWS Bedrock, Vertex AI): builds governance for their stack only — deepens lock-in. KMU with SAP + M365 + on-premise DMS need cross-cloud governance. NeuraPlox is cloud-agnostic by design — structurally unreplicable by single-cloud vendors
metrics: Price: €24K/yr vs. Dataiku €48K (2×) vs. Palantir €150K+ (6×+)
Moat: Cross-cloud agent governance — impossible for single-cloud vendors to replicate
slides.speaker_notes: The existential question every investor asks: what if Microsoft bundles EU AI Act compliance into Azure for free? The answer is structural: Azure can only govern Azure workloads. A typical Mittelstand company runs SAP on-premise, Microsoft 365 in the cloud, and a DMS from a German vendor. Azure AI Foundry cannot govern a SAP connector or an on-premise vector database — it is architecturally impossible without building connectors to its competitors' ecosystems. NeuraPlox governs across all of them because it sits above the cloud layer, not inside it. That is a durable structural advantage, not a timing advantage.
slides.transition_to_next: The white space is real — but only if the team can fill it. Let me introduce the people building NeuraPlox.
vc_alignment_notes: Directly rebuts hyperscaler commoditisation risk — Earlybird's technical partners will probe this
Cloud-agnostic governance mirrors European sovereignty thesis — no single-vendor dependency
Structural moat argument (cross-cloud governance) is stronger than feature moat (3D-Policy-Model alone)

slides.title: Enterprise Credibility Meets Startup Execution
slides.headline: Founders with 15+ years at PwC, TÜV SÜD, Allianz, Oliver Wyman — who built a 20-engineer team bootstrapped in 24 months.
bullets: Christoph Knöll — CEO & Architect: Ex-PwC Senior Manager (Business Transformation), TÜV SÜD Innovator; led AI transformation in manufacturing, logistics, and financial services
Sylvia Knöll — COO & Transformation: Ex-Allianz/Oliver Wyman; enterprise change management, partner channel, customer success
Engineering (18): Kubernetes, ML/AI, German NLP, EU AI Act compliance — 25+ deployments incl. warehouse logistics AI and industrial process automation
Advisory board (building): Recruiting industrial Mittelstand CTO; open to Earlybird portfolio introductions (remberg, EthonAI network)
metrics: Combined enterprise experience: 15+ years (PwC, TÜV SÜD, Allianz, Oliver Wyman)
Team assembled bootstrapped: 20 engineers in 24 months
Certifications: TÜV SÜD AI training programme
slides.speaker_notes: The thing that makes this team unusual is not just the credentials — it is the combination. Christoph spent years at PwC watching large enterprises fail to transfer AI methodology to mid-market clients, then spent two years at Neurawork watching mid-market clients fail at AI execution for a precise and fixable reason. NeuraPlox is not a product someone ideated from outside the market — it is the direct output of 25 painful project learnings distilled into reusable infrastructure. That practitioner lineage is the reason the technical architecture is as detailed and risk-aware as it is.
slides.transition_to_next: Given this team and this traction, let me show you the financial picture — where we are, where we are going, and what we need to get there.
vc_alignment_notes: 25+ projects across manufacturing and logistics provides industrial domain evidence matching Earlybird portfolio (remberg, EthonAI, Energy Robotics)
Advisory board signal shows awareness of industrial vertical gap and willingness to address it
Bootstrapped team assembly demonstrates capital efficiency and talent attraction

slides.title: Profitable Services Base — Raising to Scale the Platform
slides.headline: €2M/year services revenue covers all 20 FTE. The raise funds platform commercialisation on an 18-month runway with clear milestone mechanics.
bullets: Current base: ~€2M/year services revenue (20 FTE fully covered); ZIM €236K non-dilutive approved; zero external equity to date
Cash bridge: €2M services + €2.5M raise + €236K ZIM = €4.7M over 18 months; ~€200K/month burn, services cover €167K → net €33K/month from raise; 18+ months runway with >€500K buffer
ARR trajectory: Year 1: €600K (10 × €60K) · Year 2: €2.4M (40 customers) · Year 3: €3.0–3.5M (50 DACH + first EU markets)
Capital efficiency: Burn multiple <1.5×; gross margin 65% → 78%+; services base as downside protection
metrics: Services revenue: ~€2M/year (20 FTE covered)
Total 18-month resources: €4.7M (services + raise + ZIM)
Net monthly platform investment from raise: ~€33K
Year 1 ARR: €600K · Year 3: €3.0–3.5M
Burn multiple target: <1.5×
slides.speaker_notes: The cash bridge arithmetic: we generate ~€167K/month from services, covering all 20 FTE. Total all-in burn including the 4 new hires will be ~€200K/month. So the net draw on investor capital is ~€33K/month — meaning the €2.5M raise gives us 18+ months of runway with over €500K buffer. Even if platform conversion takes 6 months longer than planned, we do not run out of money — the services business sustains us. That is the structural advantage of a bootstrapped company raising its first round.
slides.transition_to_next: Which brings me to what we are asking for and precisely how we will deploy it.
vc_alignment_notes: Capital efficiency narrative is central to Earlybird's thesis — burn multiple target of <1.5× and revenue-to-raised ratio approaching 1:1 directly address stated investment criteria
Non-dilutive ZIM grant financing signals ability to leverage non-equity capital — Earlybird values founders who protect cap table
Services business as operational base eliminates existential runway risk — Earlybird can assess this as acceleration bet, not survival bet
Gross margin trajectory from 65%→78% shows improving unit economics — consistent with platform business scaling characteristics Earlybird portfolio companies exhibit

slides.title: €2.5M Seed: From Prototype to €1.5M ARR in 18 Months
slides.headline: €2.5M funds the commercial sprint from validated prototype to 20+ paying customers — the proof point for a €10–15M Series A.

Why Earlybird: Portfolio synergies — remberg (industrial AI data), HiveMQ (IoT), EthonAI (quality inspection) as Plox ecosystem partners; NeuraPlox is the Mittelstand infrastructure layer your portfolio needs
metrics: Raise: €2.5M seed + €236K ZIM
18-month: €1.5M ARR · ≥20 customers · ≥3 ISV partners

slides.speaker_notes: The portfolio argument is specific: remberg's industrial maintenance AI generates data that a Mittelstand factory could process through NeuraPlox's governance layer. HiveMQ's IoT streams could feed into NeuraPlox's Unified Data Access Layer. EthonAI's quality inspection models could run as certified Ploxe on NeuraPlox's Agent Registry. We are not claiming these integrations exist — we are saying the architecture is designed for exactly this kind of ecosystem interplay. NeuraPlox fills the infrastructure gap between Earlybird's application-layer portfolio companies and the SME customers they collectively serve.

Burn multiple and NDR targets directly address stated criteria

slides.title: Architecture Deep-Dive: Open Core, Proprietary Governance
slides.headline: Open standards at the base drive adoption. Proprietary governance creates switching costs. Network effects in the Agent Registry compound over time.
bullets: L1–L3 (Open): Kubernetes + ArgoCD + MLflow + Feast + pgvector + Hybrid-Search RAG + multi-provider LLM gateway — open-source components reduce adoption friction, community-maintained

L4–L6 (Proprietary — Core IP): 3D-Policy-Model (Agent Identity × Action × Data) — agents as First-Class governed identities; Prompt Firewall + Output Control (<2s latency target); German PII detection (>95% precision/recall); OpenTelemetry + Langfuse observability with per-agent cost attribution
L7 (Network effects): Agent Registry with 3-tier certification; open SDK for ISVs; marketplace distribution — every new Plox increases platform value for all customers
Asymmetric moat: L1–L3 open-sourced to build community; L4–L7 proprietary to capture value — the governance layer is the commercial moat the EU AI Act makes mandatory
metrics: RAG accuracy: +15–30% vs. pure vector search
PII detection: >95% precision/recall on German business documents
Policy pipeline: <2s for 4-stage cascade
IP: Trademark filed (DPMA), patent in preparation (3D-Policy-Model), trade secret (L4–L7)
slides.speaker_notes: For technical due diligence: the execution layers are open standards because proprietary runtime creates lock-in risk. Our moat is what we built above it. The 3D-Policy-Model is genuinely novel — no existing product manages AI agents as identity-bearing entities with individual permission matrices. The Agent Registry creates network effects: more ISVs building Ploxe means more value per customer and higher switching costs. A separate technical architecture memo is available for deep-dive DD. But the commercial bottom line is this: every layer you see here is a layer the customer does not have to build — and that is €48–90K of savings on the first project alone.
slides.transition_to_next: Every layer you see here is a layer the customer does not build — €48–90K saved on the first project alone. We are ready for a technical deep-dive and can arrange pilot customer reference calls within one week.
vc_alignment_notes: Technical depth slide directly addresses Earlybird's 'AI as infrastructure with proprietary data moats' and 'deep tech with clear commercialisation path' criteria
Open/closed asymmetric strategy (L1–L3 open, L4–L7 proprietary) mirrors successful Earlybird portfolio patterns (HiveMQ open-source core, enterprise features proprietary)
Network effects in Agent Registry ecosystem create platform-level defensibility — consistent with category creation thesis
German PII detection as a specific technical challenge signals vertical specialisation and domain depth — not generic AI tooling
Patent strategy and IP protection demonstrate commercial seriousness appropriate for an institutional investor conversation

narrative_arc: Neurawork has spent 2 years inside the KMU AI failure problem — 25+ projects, 20 engineers, bootstrapped profitability — and discovered the root cause: not lack of use cases but lack of reusable infrastructure. NeuraPlox is the answer: a 7-layer AI operating system for the European Mittelstand that turns a 6-month, €150K infrastructure build into a 6-week, €24K/year platform subscription. The EU AI Act, effective across all 27 member states, creates uniform compliance-driven demand — making this not a DACH product but a European infrastructure platform with a capital-efficient German beachhead. The story moves from systemic pain (86% want AI, only 23% succeed) through a technically defensible product (7 layers, agent-centric governance, N+M not N×M) to a capital-efficient, founder-operated business with €2M/year services revenue, 4 live pilots, a €1.5B DACH SAM expanding to €4–5B EU-wide, and a clear path from ZIM-funded prototype to €3M ARR.
gaps_identified: ARR: Pre-revenue on platform; pilots converting to paid in Q1 Year 1
NDR: Pre-commercial; target >120% via Plox expansion
Gross margin: Estimated from SaaS + managed service comparables (65% → 78%+)
Named customers: 4 pilots anonymised by sector (NDA); reference calls available upon request
CAC/payback: Pre-commercial; estimated from architecture assessment conversion funnel
